## 6.1. False Positives / Negatives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__false_positives_negatives}
When a security solution detects a threat, but no threat exists, that is a *false positive*. Depending on the complexity

of the solution it may utilize a set of rules, indicators of compromise, or possibly even artificial intelligence to

trigger its warning system. In the case of a solution that creates a lot of false positives, it can be tiring for a team

to go through each alert. Eventually teams are conditioned to ignore the alerts, making the security solution useless.

The key to lowering the false positive rate of a system is to better tune the rule set used to trigger the warnings. A

security team may spend time determining a baseline of events and looking for abnormalities that correspond to actual

attacks. This information can then be used to build a better detection system.

::::: example

::: example-title

Webroot Antivirus

:::

::: example-content

[In 2017 a popular antivirus service created a bad rule that identified certain Windows operating system files as

threats.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/popular-antivirus-program-mistakenly-ids-windows-threat-creating-chaos-n750521){.link}

The antivirus solution quarantined these files, which were critical for the operation of the machine. The result was a

machine that was unusable.

For 13 minutes, Webroot distributed this rule to its antivirus software shutting down operations on an untold number of

machines. Fortunately Webroot was able to quickly identify the problem and send out an update which would have allowed

the machines to automatically fix the problem. Unfortunately their infrastructure for distributing the update quickly

became overloaded.

:::

:::::

When a security solution fails to identify a threat, this is known as a *false negative*. While no solution can ever be

100% effective, false negatives can undermine confidence in a product. False negatives may be resolved by a skilled SOC

team, closely monitoring what is happening. It is also possible to address false negatives through *Layered Security* a

concept that we will cover next.

::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.2. Layered Security"}
topic: The limitations of detection-based security solutions and the need for layered security approaches.
question: Which of the following best explains why layered security is essential, even when detection-based security solutions are meticulously tuned to minimize false positives and false negatives?

choices.A: Because no detection-based solution can eliminate all vulnerabilities due to inherent limitations in identifying every possible threat.
choices.B: Because layered security reduces maintenance costs by simplifying rule sets in detection systems.
choices.C: Because detection-based solutions are always slower than attackers, regardless of configuration.
choices.D: Because layered security guarantees 100% prevention of both false positives and false negatives.

explanation: Even with optimal tuning, detection-based solutions cannot guarantee identification of all threats or complete accuracy due to the evolving and complex nature of attacks. Layered security is essential because it provides multiple, overlapping defenses to mitigate risks that detection alone cannot fully address. Options B and C misattribute the value of layered security, and D is incorrect because no security approach can guarantee absolute prevention.

context: ## 1.2. Learning the Lingo {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__learning_the_lingo} In general, the technical fields are laden with acronyms and obtuse vocabulary. Unfortunately security is no exception to this rule. Three of the most important acronyms you should be aware of to start are *CIA*, *AAA*, and *DRY*. ::: {.section .sect3 title="1.2.1. CIA"} ### 1.2.1. CIA {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cia} While the Central Intelligence Agency does have a role to play in information security, for our purposes CIA is an acronym used to remember the three foundational information security principles: confidentiality, integrity, and availability. These ideas form the cornerstone of security and should be ever-present in your thoughts. *Confidentiality* refers to the practice of keeping secret information secret. For example, if an e-commerce site stores credit card numbers (a questionable practice to begin with) those credit card numbers should be kept *confidential*. You would not want other users of the site or outsiders to have access to your credit card number. Many steps could be taken to ensure the confidentiality of user credit card numbers, but at this point it is enough to understand that maintaining confidentiality is a principle of security. *Integrity* is an assurance that data has not been corrupted or purposefully tampered with. As we discussed previously, data is very valuable, but how valuable is it if you can't be sure it is intact and reliable? In security we strive to maintain integrity so that the system and even the controls we have in place to guard the system can be trusted. Imagine that e-commerce site again. What would happen if an attacker could arbitrarily change delivery addresses stored in the system? Packages could be routed to improper addresses and stolen and honest customers would not receive what they ordered, all because of an integrity violation. *Availability* means that a system should remain up and running to ensure that valid users have access to the data when needed. In the simplest sense, you could ensure confidentiality and integrity by simply taking the system off line and not allowing any access. Such a system would be useless and this final principle addresses that. Systems are designed to be accessible and part of your security plan should be ensuring that they are. You will need to account for the costs of implementing confidentiality and integrity and make sure that the resources are available to keep the system working. In an extreme case, denial of service (DoS) attacks can actually target availability. By keeping this principle in mind, hopefully you can mitigate some of those risks. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="1.2.2. AAA"}
topic: The importance of data integrity and the impact of data corruption or tampering on trust and business operations.
question: Which of the following best illustrates why a breach of data integrity can undermine both operational effectiveness and stakeholder trust more severely than a breach of confidentiality or availability alone in a business context?

choices.A: Because loss of data integrity can render both data and the controls meant to protect it unreliable, leading to compromised business processes and eroded trust.
choices.B: Because a breach of confidentiality only exposes data to unauthorized users, while availability breaches simply prevent access, without affecting the correctness of business operations.
choices.C: Because confidentiality and availability violations are always reversible, but integrity breaches permanently damage business reputation.
choices.D: Because only data integrity breaches can result in legal action against a company, unlike confidentiality or availability breaches.

explanation: Option A is correct because loss of integrity undermines not just the data itself but also the systems and controls designed to protect it, causing failures in business processes and eroding trust among stakeholders. Options B, C, and D are misleading or factually incorrect: B oversimplifies the impacts of confidentiality and availability breaches; C is false as all types can affect reputation; D is incorrect as legal consequences can arise from all forms of security breaches.

topic: The definition and multifaceted role of protocols in dictating communication, including syntax, error correction, synchronization, and their broader relevance in computer security.
question: Which statement best encapsulates the multifaceted significance of protocols in computer security, considering their technical definition, development processes, and impact on system vulnerabilities?

choices.A: Protocols are static sets of rules focused solely on syntax, and their relevance to security is limited to preventing data corruption during communication.
choices.B: Protocols are evolving frameworks that not only dictate communication aspects like syntax, error correction, and synchronization, but whose weaknesses and development processes critically influence system attack surfaces and defense strategies.
choices.C: Protocols are exclusively software-based constructs developed by individual programmers, primarily serving to ensure compatibility between different operating systems.
choices.D: Protocols are informal guidelines published by industry associations, important mainly for their historical role in the growth of networking technologies.

explanation: Only option B captures protocols as dynamic, technically multifaceted frameworks encompassing syntax, error correction, and synchronization, developed through collaborative processes, and whose vulnerabilities directly affect computer security. The other options each omit key elements, misunderstand the scope, or misrepresent the developmental and security-related aspects of protocols.

topic: The importance of restricting open ports to only necessary services in the context of secure system and network configuration.
question: Which of the following best explains why restricting open ports to only necessary services is critical in secure system and network configuration, particularly regarding the distinction between well-known and registered ports?

choices.A: Because open ports, regardless of privilege requirements, allow any service to be exploited, making privilege separation irrelevant.
choices.B: Because unnecessary open ports, especially in the registered range, increase attack surface by allowing unprivileged users to run vulnerable services without administrative oversight.
choices.C: Because only well-known ports are vulnerable to attacks, as registered ports are inherently secure due to lack of administrative restrictions.
choices.D: Because closing all ports except those in the dynamic/private range ensures that only trusted applications can communicate, minimizing risk.

explanation: The risk is heightened with unnecessary open ports—especially in the registered range—because services can be run without administrative control, making it easier for attackers to exploit vulnerable or unauthorized services, thus increasing the attack surface.

### 10.1.3. Container Orchestration Systems {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__container_orchestration_systems}
Containers also make it easier to restart or scale applications. Container orchestration systems leverage this by

monitoring containers and bringing them up or down as needed. The most popular container orchestration system is

[Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/){.link}, developed by Google to manage web applications.

Given the orchestration systems create containers from images as needed, one of the obvious areas of concern is the

integrity of those images. If an image registry is compromised the orchestration system will still deploy the images

stored there typically making the issue far worse. Containers can also be hard to manage from a logging standpoint,

which may cause compliance issues. Whereas a company may have monitored the logs of a single server in the past, they

now have to monitor the logs of hundreds of containers running on a server.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.4. IaaS"}


### 10.1.4. IaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__iaas}
IaaS stands for infrastructure as a service and it refers to purchasing VMs or container resources from a provider. Some

popular IaaS companies are Amazon Web Systems, Microsoft Azure, and Linode. Each has some basic security tools and

default policies in place to help keep the purchased resources secure, but ultimately most of the security

responsibility for making sure the resources are secure lies with the group purchasing the resource.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.5. PaaS"}
topic: Security implications of container orchestration systems with specific emphasis on image integrity and registry compromise.
question: Which of the following best explains why a compromised container image registry poses a unique and amplified security risk in environments managed by container orchestration systems?

choices.A: Orchestration systems will immediately terminate compromised containers upon detection, limiting impact.
choices.B: Orchestration systems dynamically pull and deploy images from registries, allowing rapid and large-scale distribution of malicious images before detection.
choices.C: Orchestration systems require manual intervention to deploy new containers, reducing the risk of widespread compromise.
choices.D: Orchestration systems isolate all containers from the underlying host, preventing malicious images from affecting system integrity.

explanation: The core risk is that orchestration systems are designed to automatically deploy and scale containers by pulling images from registries as needed. If a registry is compromised, this automation enables attackers to propagate malicious images quickly and extensively across the environment, outpacing detection and remediation efforts.

## 4.1. Network Access Layer {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__network_access_layer}
::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.1. ARP"}


### 4.1.1. ARP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__arp}
Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is used on the local ethernet segment to resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses. Since

this protocol functions at the ethernet segment level, security was not a primary concern. Unfortunately this means that

ARP communications can be easily spoofed to cause a MitM scenario. A malicious actor simply sends out several ARP

packets, *gratuitous arp*, saying that traffic for a certain IP address should be sent to them. Since the MAC to IP

address table is cached in several places, it can take a long time for all the caches to invalidate and resolve an issue

caused by malicious ARP frames.

There is a protocol designed to mitigate the issues with ARP. Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) reaches across layers to work

with the DHCP lease database and drop packets that are not using the MAC address used when a DHCP lease was granted.

While this can solve many of the issues associated with ARP it is also a good practice to use secure higher-level

protocols such as HTTPS just in case.

:::

:::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.2. Wifi"}
topic: Analysis of ARP's inherent security vulnerabilities and the reasons behind its susceptibility to spoofing attacks.
question: Which fundamental characteristic of ARP most directly enables successful spoofing attacks, and why do conventional mitigation strategies like Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) not fully eliminate the risk of traffic interception?

choices.A: ARP's lack of cryptographic authentication allows any host to claim an IP-MAC mapping, and DAI relies on DHCP records, leaving static IP devices and higher-layer attacks unprotected.
choices.B: ARP packets are encrypted but not signed, so DAI cannot validate signatures, and attackers can still use DHCP-supplied addresses to bypass DAI.
choices.C: ARP tables are only updated on reboot, so spoofed entries persist indefinitely, and DAI cannot clear entries, making interception unavoidable.
choices.D: ARP only operates at layer 3, causing isolation from DHCP, and DAI cannot monitor traffic between switches, so MitM attacks persist.

explanation: The primary vulnerability is ARP's complete lack of authentication, permitting any device to send gratuitous ARP updates that poison caches. DAI can mitigate attacks involving DHCP-managed devices by cross-checking DHCP records, but it does not protect against statically assigned IP addresses or attacks at higher layers, such as application-level spoofing, thus not fully eliminating the interception risk.

choices.A: Confidentiality
choices.B: Integrity
choices.C: Availability
choices.D: Non-repudiation

context: ### 3.5.6. Impersonation/Identity Theft {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__impersonationidentity_theft} Often as part of a phishing campaign, a threat actor will pretend to be someone else. This may be someone within the organization or someone with sufficient power outside the organization, such as a representative of a government oversight agency. Attackers may also use stolen credentials to make their messages appear official, once again giving them and easy route through which to deploy malware. ::: :::::::::: :::::::::: {.section .sect2 title="3.6. Cyber Killchain"} ## 3.6. Cyber Killchain {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cyber_killchain} One way of analyzing an attack involving malware is through the steps of the Cyber Killchain. The Cyber Killchain was developed by Lockheed Martin and is a military method of analysis that has been adopted by cybersecurity. Cyber Killchain is broken into seven steps: Recon, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, Command and Control, and Exfiltration. ::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.1. Recon"}
topic: Analysis of impersonation tactics in phishing campaigns and their impact on organizational security.
question: In the context of the Cyber Killchain, at which stage does successful impersonation in a phishing campaign most significantly amplify the threat actor's ability to bypass organizational defenses, and why is this amplification particularly critical for subsequent stages of the attack?

choices.A: Recon, because impersonation enables attackers to gather sensitive information without raising suspicion.
choices.B: Delivery, because impersonation increases the likelihood that malicious payloads are accepted and executed by targets.
choices.C: Installation, because impersonation allows malware to remain undetected after initial compromise.
choices.D: Command and Control, because impersonation facilitates covert communication between compromised systems and attackers.

explanation: While impersonation can play a role in multiple stages, it is during the Delivery stage that it most significantly amplifies the attacker's ability to bypass defenses. By convincing targets that a malicious message is from a trusted source, impersonation drastically increases the chance that users will open attachments or click links, enabling the malware to be delivered and executed, which is critical for advancing through subsequent stages of the Killchain.

While the user could take these steps themselves, PaaS makes it easier to deploy an application.

:::

### 10.1.6. SaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__saas}
Software as a service (SaaS) is a methodology that we are quite used to. SaaS takes a web application and makes it

available for a subscription. Some examples would be Webex, Dropbox, Google Workspace, etc. SaaS is a popular way to

monitize software.

One of the security concerns with SaaS is that it consolidates information with a single provider. If the server running

the software is compromised, the PII of millions of people may be leaked.

:::

choices.A: SaaS providers often aggregate vast amounts of user PII within a single environment, increasing the potential impact of a single breach.
choices.B: SaaS applications are inherently more vulnerable to technical attacks than PaaS or IaaS due to less mature security frameworks.
choices.C: SaaS models require users to manage their own encryption keys, making user error the primary risk to PII.

## 6.1. False Positives / Negatives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__false_positives_negatives}
When a security solution detects a threat, but no threat exists, that is a *false positive*. Depending on the complexity

of the solution it may utilize a set of rules, indicators of compromise, or possibly even artificial intelligence to

trigger its warning system. In the case of a solution that creates a lot of false positives, it can be tiring for a team

to go through each alert. Eventually teams are conditioned to ignore the alerts, making the security solution useless.

The key to lowering the false positive rate of a system is to better tune the rule set used to trigger the warnings. A

security team may spend time determining a baseline of events and looking for abnormalities that correspond to actual

attacks. This information can then be used to build a better detection system.

::::: example

::: example-title

Webroot Antivirus

:::

::: example-content

[In 2017 a popular antivirus service created a bad rule that identified certain Windows operating system files as

threats.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/popular-antivirus-program-mistakenly-ids-windows-threat-creating-chaos-n750521){.link}

The antivirus solution quarantined these files, which were critical for the operation of the machine. The result was a

machine that was unusable.

For 13 minutes, Webroot distributed this rule to its antivirus software shutting down operations on an untold number of

machines. Fortunately Webroot was able to quickly identify the problem and send out an update which would have allowed

the machines to automatically fix the problem. Unfortunately their infrastructure for distributing the update quickly

became overloaded.

:::

:::::

When a security solution fails to identify a threat, this is known as a *false negative*. While no solution can ever be

100% effective, false negatives can undermine confidence in a product. False negatives may be resolved by a skilled SOC

team, closely monitoring what is happening. It is also possible to address false negatives through *Layered Security* a

concept that we will cover next.

::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.2. Layered Security"}
topic: The operational and psychological impacts of high false positive rates on security teams and overall system effectiveness.
question: Which of the following best illustrates a compounded risk that arises from persistently high false positive rates in security alerting systems, beyond immediate operational disruption?

choices.A: Increased likelihood of attackers exploiting alert fatigue to bypass detection.
choices.B: Improved detection of novel threats due to more sensitive rulesets.
choices.C: Reduced need for baseline event analysis in system tuning.
choices.D: Enhanced organizational confidence in automated response mechanisms.

explanation: Persistent high false positive rates can condition security teams to ignore alerts, leading to alert fatigue. This human factor creates an environment where true threats are more likely to go unnoticed, which sophisticated attackers can exploit to circumvent detection—creating a compounded risk beyond just the immediate operational disruptions caused by false alerts.

topic: The process of encrypting a message using an arbitrary substitution table, as illustrated in the provided Caesar cipher example.
question: Which property of a substitution cipher constructed using an arbitrary mapping table most fundamentally enables frequency analysis attacks to succeed, even when the substitution table is randomly generated and kept secret?

choices.A: The preservation of plaintext letter frequency patterns in the ciphertext
choices.B: The limited size of the possible keyspace due to the finite number of letter permutations
choices.C: The use of a deterministic algorithm for encryption and decryption
choices.D: The possibility of guessing the original message by brute-force permutation testing

explanation: The core vulnerability of substitution ciphers to frequency analysis is that, regardless of how the mapping is chosen, each plaintext letter is always replaced by the same ciphertext letter, preserving statistical frequency patterns from the original language. This allows an attacker to analyze ciphertext frequencies and match them to typical plaintext frequencies, making the cipher susceptible to attack even if the key is unknown.

topic: The implications of easily changeable MAC addresses for both network attack surface and legitimate network operations such as virtualization.
question: Which of the following best explains why the ability to easily change MAC addresses simultaneously increases the network attack surface and supports legitimate operations such as virtualization?

choices.A: It undermines the assumption of static device identity, enabling attacks like spoofing and flooding, while also allowing dynamic allocation of virtual machines requiring unique MAC addresses.
choices.B: It improves the efficiency of network traffic routing, reducing latency for both attackers and legitimate users in virtualized environments.
choices.C: It prevents attackers from launching ARP poisoning attacks, while supporting migration of virtual machines across subnets.
choices.D: It ensures that all network devices can use the same MAC address, simplifying management and reducing the risk of Denial-of-Service attacks.

explanation: Option A is correct because making MAC addresses easily changeable breaks the traditional link between a device and its MAC address, which attackers exploit through spoofing and flooding, but this same flexibility is essential for virtualization, where virtual machines often need to assume new MAC addresses for legitimate operation. The other options either conflate benefits (B, C) or make technically incorrect claims about network management (D).

topic: The use of URLs and domains as IoCs, and their effectiveness in revealing malware activity and infection pathways.
question: Which statement best characterizes both the advantages and limitations of using URLs and domains as indicators of compromise for revealing malware activity and infection pathways?

choices.A: URLs and domains are highly effective because they are static and unchanging, allowing persistent tracking of malware infrastructure across all campaigns.
choices.B: URLs and domains can provide insights into infection pathways, but their effectiveness is limited by the use of legitimate or frequently changing infrastructure by modern malware.
choices.C: URLs and domains, unlike hashes or IP addresses, cannot reveal infection pathways or attacker infrastructure due to their ephemeral nature.
choices.D: URLs and domains are superior to file hashes and virus signatures in detecting malware, as they never overlap with benign network activity.

explanation: Option B is correct because URLs/domains can reveal infection pathways and attacker infrastructure, but their effectiveness is undermined when malware uses legitimate services or rapidly changes web infrastructure, making detection and attribution more challenging.

### 2.10.7. Trusted Platform Module (TPM) / Hardware Security Module (HSM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__trusted_platform_module_tpm_hardware_security_module_hsm}
These modules provide hardware specifically for use with encryption. HSMs are removable modules while TPMs are

motherboard chips. Many ciphers rely on a reliable source of entropy (randomness) which these modules provide. They can

also significantly increase the speed at which cryptographic algorithms run by moving the operations to specialized

hardware. Lastly, these modules can be used to store keys *and* make them only accessible via the module. This can add

an extra layer of security to prevent the keys from being easily copied.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="2.10.8. Steganography"}


### 2.10.8. Steganography {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__steganography}
Steganography is the process of hiding data in something such that to a casual observer it cannot be detected. Data can

be hidden in audio, images, or even [plain

text!](https://dl.packetstormsecurity.net/crypt/snow/description.html){.link}. The hidden data can also be encrypted if

an additional layer of security is required. In the field of security, malicious code may be hidden inside other files

using steganographic techniques. This makes it more difficult for tools to find them when searching storage.

:::

topic: Analyze the architectural and operational differences between Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs) and Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) and their respective implications for system security.
question: Which of the following security implications most directly results from the architectural distinction between TPMs being integrated motherboard chips and HSMs being removable modules?

choices.A: TPMs offer enhanced resistance to physical extraction of cryptographic keys due to their fixed integration, while HSMs are more susceptible to physical theft and key compromise.
choices.B: HSMs can accelerate cryptographic algorithms more effectively than TPMs because they provide higher entropy sources.
choices.C: TPMs allow cryptographic keys to be shared securely across multiple systems, whereas HSMs restrict key use to a single device.
choices.D: Both TPMs and HSMs are equally vulnerable to software-based attacks due to their hardware nature, making architectural differences irrelevant for system security.

explanation: The architectural difference—TPMs being soldered to the motherboard and HSMs being removable—means TPMs are inherently more resistant to physical removal and key extraction, while HSMs’ portability introduces a risk of theft and compromise. The other options either incorrectly state operational characteristics or ignore the relevance of hardware integration to security posture.

## 9.5. MITRE ATT&CK Framework {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__mitre_attck_framework}
In the [Malware](#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__malware){.xref} chapter we covered Lockheed

Martin's Cyber Killchain attack analysis framework. Cyber killchain is not the only analysis framework available, a

popular alternative is the [MITRE ATT&CK framework](https://attack.mitre.org){.link}. ATT&CK has 14 sections that cover

adversarial tactics, techniques, and common knowledge. Each section is separated into different matrices that have their

own sub-techniques.

Developed in 2013, the ATT&CK framework is a modern way of looking at an incident that can help drive decision making

regarding response and continuity.

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.5.1. Reconnaissance"}


### 9.5.1. Reconnaissance {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__reconnaissance}
Reconnaissance is the act of collecting information about a target. This typically involves vulnerability scanning,

network mapping, and phishing. Attackers are generally looking for weak links and a way in to the company. Understanding

how reconnaissance is performed can help a security team pick up on the precursors to an incident.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.5.2. Resource Development"}
topic: In-depth exploration of the "Reconnaissance" section within ATT&CK, including its definition, techniques (vulnerability scanning, network mapping, phishing), and implications for early incident detection.
question: When designing early incident detection mechanisms using the MITRE ATT&CK framework, which of the following best illustrates the unique challenge posed by reconnaissance techniques such as vulnerability scanning, network mapping, and phishing in terms of reliably distinguishing benign from malicious activity?

choices.A: Reconnaissance techniques typically exploit zero-day vulnerabilities, making their detection nearly impossible until after initial compromise.
choices.B: The overlap between routine administrative tasks and attacker reconnaissance activities can cause false positives, complicating timely detection of adversarial intent.
choices.C: Reconnaissance activities are always performed from external sources, making internal network monitoring ineffective for early detection.
choices.D: Phishing as a reconnaissance method is easily detected by automated filters, reducing its effectiveness compared to vulnerability scanning and network mapping.

explanation: The primary challenge in detecting reconnaissance is that its techniques—vulnerability scanning, network mapping, and phishing—often mimic legitimate administrative or user behaviors, leading to difficulty in distinguishing benign from malicious actions and increasing false positives. This complicates early detection efforts, requiring nuanced analysis and context-aware monitoring.

### 10.2.3. Hybrid {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__hybrid}
Hybrid cloud uses both models, public and private, and hosts some things on public IaaS services and other on internal,

private IaaS services. This can be the best of both worlds, assuming the applications being supported leverage the full

advantages of their environment.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.2.4. Multi-Cloud"}


### 10.2.4. Multi-Cloud {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__multi_cloud}
Multi-cloud typically refers to utilizing more than one cloud provider. This may be required for applications that wish

to remain available even if their cloud provider fails. Multi-cloud also avoids the issue of vendor lock-in, where the

application is only set up to run on one provider.

From a security standpoint, multi-cloud likely increases the attack surface of an application. You now have to be

concerned with the vulnerabilities of two providers instead of just one. This must be weighed against the benefits of

redundancy when deciding whether or not to utilize more than one cloud provider.

:::

:::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="10.3. Serverless Solutions"}
topic: Strategic considerations in selecting between hybrid cloud and multi-cloud models for organizational needs.
question: When a large enterprise seeks to minimize vendor lock-in and maximize application availability, but is also highly sensitive to expanding its security attack surface, which cloud strategy is most likely to introduce the greatest operational complexity while addressing the enterprise's core objectives?

choices.A: Sole reliance on a private cloud
choices.B: Hybrid cloud deployment
choices.C: Multi-cloud deployment
choices.D: Public cloud deployment with regional redundancy

explanation: Multi-cloud deployment best addresses both minimizing vendor lock-in and maximizing availability, but it does so at the cost of increased operational complexity and an expanded attack surface, as multiple providers must be managed and secured.

### 3.6.1. Recon {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__recon}
Recon is short for reconnaissance, military parlance for a preliminary survey used to gain information. During the recon

phase, a malicious actor will gather as much information as possible. Methods used in this phase may be passive or

active.

Passive recon involves gathering information *without* sending anything to the target. This typically involves accessing

publicly available information, such as social media, published websites, and DNS records. If the actor has access they

may also passively sniff network packets.

Active recon involves interaction with the target. This can include port scanning, vulnerability scanning, [brute

forcing directories and filenames on an HTTP server](https://www.kali.org/tools/dirbuster/){.link}, or even contacting

workers. Active recon can yield more information, but it is also significantly easier to detect.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.2. Weaponization"}


### 3.6.2. Weaponization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__weaponization}
In the weaponization phase the actor begins readying exploits for the vulnerabilities that were assessed during recon.

This may include tailoring malware, creating phishing emails, customizing tools, and preparing an environment for the

attack. For malware to be effective it must utilize the correct exploits and work under the correct OS and environment.

[Metasploit](https://www.metasploit.com/){.link} is a penetration testing framework that is often used in this step to

create custom malware.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.3. Delivery"}
topic: The types of information that can be gathered during passive reconnaissance and their potential value to an attacker.
question: Which of the following types of information, if obtained during passive reconnaissance, would most significantly enhance an attacker's ability to craft highly targeted social engineering attacks?

choices.A: Publicly available employee social media profiles describing job roles and project involvement
choices.B: Open ports and running services discovered via external port scanning
choices.C: Internally used hostnames obtained from intercepted internal network traffic
choices.D: Directory structure revealed through web server brute force enumeration

explanation: Publicly available social media profiles can provide detailed insights into employee roles, relationships, and current projects, which can be leveraged to design convincing, highly targeted social engineering attacks. The other options either typically require active probing (B, D) or internal network access (C), making them less relevant or unattainable via passive recon.

Managing Risk {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__managing_risk} *Information security* (infosec) is largely the practice of preventing *unauthorized access* to data. Unauthorized access is when an actor gains access to data that they do not have the permissions to access. The system is often used in an unintended manner to provide such access. Data has become an increasingly valuable asset and the *risks* of others having access to data are incredibly high. Because of this, information security typically falls under the risk-management plan of a company and its importance cannot be understated. This is evidenced by the fact that information technology's (IT) typical role in a company has migrated from a basic service provider to directorships with a seat at the highest decision making table. This is directly due to the fact that IT assets have become the most valuable things many companies own. Guarding these assets and managing the inherent risk of their loss is the job of information security professionals. *Malicious software*, also referred to as malware, is often employed to help an attacker gain access to a system. Many types of malicious software exist, but the common thread is that they perform actions that cause harm to a computer system or network. In the case of many attacks, *system failure* may occur either as an intended (as is the case in Denial of Service (DoS) attacks) or unintended consequence. This means the system will no longer be able to perform its intended purpose. System failure is a serious risk that needs to be managed. ::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.2. Learning the Lingo"}

question: Which organizational shift is most directly attributable to the recognition of data as a critical asset with high risks of unauthorized disclosure, as described in the context?

choices.A: The transition of IT functions from operational support to strategic leadership roles within top executive decision-making.
choices.B: The outsourcing of all IT infrastructure to external vendors to minimize internal risk exposure.
choices.C: The implementation of mandatory annual security awareness training for all employees.
choices.D: The decentralization of risk management responsibilities to individual business units.

explanation: The context explicitly links the growing value of data and the high risk of its compromise with the elevation of IT from a basic service provider to a directorship participating in the highest levels of organizational decision-making—a strategic shift in governance reflecting the central importance of data.

topic: Assess the implications of aligning weekly assignments, reviews, and quizzes with specific chapters and learning outcomes for expert competency development in computer systems security.
question: Which of the following best explains a significant pedagogical advantage of aligning weekly assignments, reviews, and quizzes directly with specific chapters and mapped learning outcomes in the context of developing expert competency in computer systems security?

choices.A: It enables efficient rote memorization of security concepts without the need for practical application.
choices.B: It ensures systematic reinforcement and assessment of targeted competencies, facilitating mastery through iterative feedback and cumulative integration.
choices.C: It allows instructors to reduce the overall number of assessments required for course completion.
choices.D: It minimizes the need for alignment between instructional materials and real-world security scenarios.

explanation: The key pedagogical advantage is that direct alignment provides structured opportunities for students to practice, receive feedback, and demonstrate mastery of specific competencies in a progressive, cumulative manner, which is critical for expert development in a complex, evolving field like computer systems security.

topic: Potential strategies and limitations for defending against MAC spoofing and MAC flooding attacks within switch-based networks.
question: Which defense mechanism most effectively mitigates both MAC spoofing and MAC flooding attacks in switch-based networks, while also accounting for the operational needs of environments with legitimate MAC address changes, and what is a primary limitation of this approach?

choices.A: Enabling port security with strict static MAC address binding; limitation is inability to accommodate legitimate MAC changes needed for virtualization.
choices.B: Implementing dynamic ARP inspection; limitation is increased processing overhead on the switch.
choices.C: Using port security with a configurable maximum number of dynamic MAC addresses per port; limitation is potential for legitimate device displacement or denial of service if the threshold is exceeded.
choices.D: Segmenting the network with VLANs; limitation is increased administrative complexity and does not directly address MAC-layer attacks.

explanation: Option C allows the switch to learn a limited number of MAC addresses per port, preventing table overflows (MAC flooding) and constraining spoofing without strictly binding to static addresses, which supports environments where MAC addresses change legitimately. The main limitation is that legitimate devices may be denied access if the dynamic limit is reached, leading to potential disruption.

### 10.1.3. Container Orchestration Systems {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__container_orchestration_systems}
Containers also make it easier to restart or scale applications. Container orchestration systems leverage this by

monitoring containers and bringing them up or down as needed. The most popular container orchestration system is

[Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/){.link}, developed by Google to manage web applications.

Given the orchestration systems create containers from images as needed, one of the obvious areas of concern is the

integrity of those images. If an image registry is compromised the orchestration system will still deploy the images

stored there typically making the issue far worse. Containers can also be hard to manage from a logging standpoint,

which may cause compliance issues. Whereas a company may have monitored the logs of a single server in the past, they

now have to monitor the logs of hundreds of containers running on a server.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.4. IaaS"}


### 10.1.4. IaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__iaas}
IaaS stands for infrastructure as a service and it refers to purchasing VMs or container resources from a provider. Some

popular IaaS companies are Amazon Web Systems, Microsoft Azure, and Linode. Each has some basic security tools and

default policies in place to help keep the purchased resources secure, but ultimately most of the security

responsibility for making sure the resources are secure lies with the group purchasing the resource.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.5. PaaS"}
topic: The effects of dynamic scaling and container lifecycle management on overall system security and monitoring.
question: When operating a containerized environment with dynamic scaling and automated container lifecycle management, which factor poses the greatest systemic risk to both overall security and effective monitoring, and why?

choices.A: Insufficient container image integrity validation, as compromised images can be rapidly and widely propagated through orchestration.
choices.B: Overprovisioning compute resources, leading to increased operational costs and potential resource exhaustion.
choices.C: Network segmentation issues, resulting in containers being unable to communicate efficiently.
choices.D: Use of default security policies from IaaS providers, increasing the risk of external attacks through misconfiguration.

explanation: Dynamic scaling and automated lifecycles mean containers are instantiated and destroyed frequently, often based on images pulled from registries. If image integrity is not strictly validated, a compromised image can be rapidly deployed across the infrastructure, magnifying the impact of a single breach. Additionally, high container churn complicates centralized monitoring and logging, making both detection and compliance more challenging. While other risks exist, the systemic risk from compromised images, in conjunction with orchestration, is both foundational and uniquely amplified by dynamic scaling.

## 4.1. Network Access Layer {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__network_access_layer}
::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.1. ARP"}


### 4.1.1. ARP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__arp}
Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is used on the local ethernet segment to resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses. Since

this protocol functions at the ethernet segment level, security was not a primary concern. Unfortunately this means that

ARP communications can be easily spoofed to cause a MitM scenario. A malicious actor simply sends out several ARP

packets, *gratuitous arp*, saying that traffic for a certain IP address should be sent to them. Since the MAC to IP

address table is cached in several places, it can take a long time for all the caches to invalidate and resolve an issue

caused by malicious ARP frames.

There is a protocol designed to mitigate the issues with ARP. Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) reaches across layers to work

with the DHCP lease database and drop packets that are not using the MAC address used when a DHCP lease was granted.

While this can solve many of the issues associated with ARP it is also a good practice to use secure higher-level

protocols such as HTTPS just in case.

:::

:::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.2. Wifi"}
topic: Examination of how ARP spoofing, particularly through gratuitous ARP packets, can facilitate Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks.
question: Which of the following best explains why Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI), even when properly configured, does not fully eliminate the risk of Man-in-the-Middle attacks facilitated by gratuitous ARP packets on a local network segment?

choices.A: DAI can be bypassed if attackers compromise the DHCP server itself, allowing them to inject malicious MAC-to-IP bindings directly.
choices.B: DAI only validates ARP packets against the DHCP lease database, so devices using static IP assignments outside of DHCP scope remain vulnerable to ARP spoofing.
choices.C: DAI is ineffective against ARP spoofing attacks that originate from remote segments rather than the local network.
choices.D: DAI can delay legitimate ARP updates, causing temporary network outages that attackers can exploit to sustain MitM attacks.

explanation: While DAI significantly mitigates ARP spoofing by validating ARP packets against the DHCP lease database, devices that use static IP addresses—thus not present in the DHCP database—are not protected by DAI and can still be targeted by gratuitous ARP packets. This leaves a security gap, necessitating additional protections like secure application-layer protocols.

context: ### 4.4.15. SNMP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__snmp} ::: float-group Simple Network Management Protocol is used for gathering information about the workings of a network. It is broken into two groups: clients using UDP port 161 (TLS 10161) and a manager using UDP port 162 (TLS 10162). The manager collects messages from the clients regarding the operations of the network and uses this information to take actions as necessary. SNMP can be used to pass information about the temperature of a machine, how many connections it currently has, the channel capacity currently being utilized, etc. SNMP is currently up to version 3 which is encrypted and requires authentication. This is particularly important because SNMP is a very powerful protocol which exchanges information that could potentially be very valuable to an attacker. Access to SNMP should be limited and its usage on a network should be monitored. ::: :::: :::::::::::::::::::::: ::::::::: {.section .sect2 title="4.5. Lab: Scanning with nmap"}
topic: The types of network and system information that can be collected and monitored using SNMP and the implications for network management.
question: Which of the following best illustrates both the practical benefits and the security implications of using SNMP for network management in a modern enterprise environment?

choices.A: SNMP enables automated firmware updates and ensures software compliance, but may expose patch information to attackers if not properly secured.
choices.B: SNMP allows real-time monitoring of device temperature, connection counts, and bandwidth utilization, providing operational visibility while also risking disclosure of critical infrastructure data to adversaries if access controls are weak.
choices.C: SNMP facilitates end-to-end encryption of user data in transit and automates incident response, but may be bypassed by encrypted traffic.
choices.D: SNMP manages firewall rule deployment across distributed networks, but can inadvertently allow unauthorized rule changes if misconfigured.

explanation: Option B is correct because SNMP is designed for monitoring operational metrics such as temperature, connection counts, and bandwidth usage, which greatly aid network management. However, this same detailed information can be exploited by attackers if SNMP access is not tightly controlled, making security and monitoring essential. The other options attribute functions to SNMP that are outside its core capabilities or misstate its operational role.

context: ## One-time Passwords ::: content To help mitigate replay attacks, an online banking application may require that client use a one-time password (OTP) when submitting transactions. An OTP is a frequently changing value that is known to both the client and the server. Several one-time password schemes exist, most of which make use of a cryptographic hash function with a shared seed between client and server. Periodically the client and server update to a new hash based on the seed and without the seed it is impossible to know what the next hash will be. By using an OTP anyone who intercepts the traffic will not be able to perform a replay attack as the password will not be current. ::: :::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="5.1.4. SSL Circumvention"} ### 5.1.4. SSL Circumvention {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ssl_circumvention} If you think about the intercepted key exchange given in the above MitM example, a similar attack can allow attackers to view SSL traffic. The attacker gives the victim a bogus certificate authority (CA) certificate which the victim installs. This is often accomplished via a trojan. Then the attacker places themselves in the middle of an uninitiated secure connection. During the key exchange the attacker creates a custom certificate signed by a bogus CA for the connection between attacker and victim. The attacker also makes an actual HTTPS connection to the service and proxies data for the victim. All of the victims data will show up in plaintext for the attacker but the connection will appear to be secure for the victim. This is used in the [Fiddler](https://www.telerik.com/fiddler){.link} debugging proxy to decrypt HTTPS traffic and is also used in some network appliances that perform deep packet inspection. Another MitM attack on SSL is simply to maintain or downgrade to an HTTP connection with the victim and proxy data to an actual HTTPS connection with the server. Most servers will upgrade an insecure connection, but by intercepting that exchange the attacker can continue to monitor the victim's traffic. ::: :::::::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="5.2. Network Layer Attacks"}
topic: The process by which attackers trick victims into installing malicious CA certificates and the resulting vulnerabilities in SSL/TLS connections.
question: Which of the following best explains why installing a malicious certificate authority (CA) certificate on a victim's device fundamentally compromises the security of SSL/TLS connections, even when the victim accesses legitimate HTTPS sites?

choices.A: It allows attackers to generate valid-looking certificates for any domain, enabling interception and decryption of secure traffic without browser warnings.
choices.B: It only enables attackers to view traffic for sites with expired certificates, leaving most connections protected.
choices.C: It prevents all secure connections, causing users to be unable to access any HTTPS websites.
choices.D: It merely enables attackers to inject malicious content into HTTP pages but not affect encrypted HTTPS connections.

explanation: Installing a malicious CA certificate allows attackers to create certificates for any website that the victim's device will trust, making it possible to intercept, decrypt, and modify any supposedly secure traffic without alerting the user—effectively bypassing the entire SSL/TLS trust model.

### 10.1.3. Container Orchestration Systems {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__container_orchestration_systems}
Containers also make it easier to restart or scale applications. Container orchestration systems leverage this by

monitoring containers and bringing them up or down as needed. The most popular container orchestration system is

[Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/){.link}, developed by Google to manage web applications.

Given the orchestration systems create containers from images as needed, one of the obvious areas of concern is the

integrity of those images. If an image registry is compromised the orchestration system will still deploy the images

stored there typically making the issue far worse. Containers can also be hard to manage from a logging standpoint,

which may cause compliance issues. Whereas a company may have monitored the logs of a single server in the past, they

now have to monitor the logs of hundreds of containers running on a server.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.4. IaaS"}


### 10.1.4. IaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__iaas}
IaaS stands for infrastructure as a service and it refers to purchasing VMs or container resources from a provider. Some

popular IaaS companies are Amazon Web Systems, Microsoft Azure, and Linode. Each has some basic security tools and

default policies in place to help keep the purchased resources secure, but ultimately most of the security

responsibility for making sure the resources are secure lies with the group purchasing the resource.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.5. PaaS"}
topic: Risk assessment and mitigation strategies for organizations adopting container orchestration and IaaS solutions.
question: When an organization adopts both container orchestration and IaaS solutions, which of the following mitigation strategies most directly addresses a risk uniquely exacerbated by the dynamic deployment nature of container orchestration systems?

choices.A: Implement centralized log aggregation and analysis for all container instances
choices.B: Enforce strict image signing and verification for all container images before deployment
choices.C: Rely on IaaS provider's default network security policies
choices.D: Use host-based intrusion detection systems on all virtual machines

explanation: The dynamic deployment of containers by orchestration systems heightens the risk of rapid, widespread compromise if image integrity is breached. Enforcing image signing and verification directly mitigates the risk of deploying compromised or unauthorized images, which is uniquely exacerbated by automated and large-scale container deployment.

### 4.4.9. DNS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dns}
Domain Name System (DNS) is used to resolve domain names to IP addresses. Domain names are the simple names people are

accustomed to for websites, such as `njit.edu`{.literal} as opposed to `54.83.189.142`{.literal}. Names are

significantly easier for people to remember than IP addresses. In order for a computer to resolve a name, it first

queries a local cache, then its primary DNS server. Assuming the DNS server cannot find the name it will query a Root

server for a Top Level Domain (TLD) server, which maintains a listing of Authoritative Nameservers for that particular

domain (edu, com, net, org, gov, etc.). Finally once an authoritative nameserver is found it will respond with the IP

address for that particular hostname which will be cached and sent back through the user's primary DNS server to the

user.

DNS is designed to be resilient and decentralized but unfortunately the traffic is not authenticated or encrypted. This

has made it a target for MitM attacks. Likewise cache hits and misses [can yield information as to what names have been

recently resolved](https://kb.isc.org/docs/aa-00509){.link} (as was the case in discovering the extent of the Sony

Rootkit). The recursive nature has of DNS has also allowed for DoS attacks in the past, but much of that has been solved

by limiting recursive queries to the user-facing DNS servers (ie. the one given to you by your DHCP request). DNS

operates via UDP (and occasionally TCP) on port 53.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.10. DNSSEC"}
topic: The role of DNS caching in both performance optimization and information leakage, with reference to security incident investigations.
question: In the context of security incident investigations, how can the performance benefits of DNS caching paradoxically enable information leakage, and which investigative technique most effectively exploits this vulnerability?

choices.A: By reducing DNS query latency, cached entries inadvertently allow attackers to infer recent domain lookups through cache probing, with cache snooping serving as the primary investigative technique.
choices.B: DNS caching improves performance but encrypts queries, thereby preventing any information leakage, making cache poisoning attacks the main investigative focus.
choices.C: The decentralization of DNS caching leads to automatic cache invalidation, which eliminates opportunities for information leakage, so only packet sniffing is relevant during investigations.
choices.D: Restricting recursive queries in DNS caching systems fully prevents information leakage, leaving only brute-force enumeration as an investigative tool.

explanation: Option A correctly identifies that DNS caching, while optimizing performance, enables information leakage by allowing analysis of cache contents to infer recent lookups; cache snooping is the investigative technique that leverages this vulnerability. The other options either misstate the role of encryption, overstate the impact of decentralization, or incorrectly assert that restricting recursion prevents leakage.

topic: The workflow and sequence of authentication and ticket acquisition in a Kerberos-secured environment.
question: Which sequence most accurately describes the process by which a client authenticates and gains access to a service in a Kerberos-secured environment?

choices.A: The client first requests a Ticket-Granting Ticket (TGT) from the TGS using the Service Principal Name (SPN), then presents the TGT to the AS to receive a service ticket, and finally connects to the service.
choices.B: The client authenticates with the Authentication Server (AS) to obtain a Ticket-Granting Ticket (TGT), presents the TGT and Service Principal Name (SPN) to the Ticket-Granting Service (TGS) to obtain a service ticket, and then uses the service ticket to access the desired service.

### 2.10.7. Trusted Platform Module (TPM) / Hardware Security Module (HSM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__trusted_platform_module_tpm_hardware_security_module_hsm}
These modules provide hardware specifically for use with encryption. HSMs are removable modules while TPMs are

motherboard chips. Many ciphers rely on a reliable source of entropy (randomness) which these modules provide. They can

also significantly increase the speed at which cryptographic algorithms run by moving the operations to specialized

hardware. Lastly, these modules can be used to store keys *and* make them only accessible via the module. This can add

an extra layer of security to prevent the keys from being easily copied.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="2.10.8. Steganography"}


### 2.10.8. Steganography {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__steganography}
Steganography is the process of hiding data in something such that to a casual observer it cannot be detected. Data can

be hidden in audio, images, or even [plain

text!](https://dl.packetstormsecurity.net/crypt/snow/description.html){.link}. The hidden data can also be encrypted if

an additional layer of security is required. In the field of security, malicious code may be hidden inside other files

using steganographic techniques. This makes it more difficult for tools to find them when searching storage.

:::

choices.A: Keys are protected from software-based exfiltration, but may become irrecoverable if the hardware module fails or is lost.
choices.B: Keys are always available to authorized software, but can still be easily copied by attackers with physical access.
choices.C: Key storage in hardware modules guarantees both perfect security and effortless migration between devices.

## 4.2. Internet Layer Protocols {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__internet_layer_protocols}
:::: {.section .sect3 title="4.2.1. IP"}


### 4.2.1. IP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ip}
IP stands for internet protocol and it was devised to allow creating a network of networks. The network of networks that

uses it primarily is the Internet, although you could use IP in other scenarios as well. IP is largely concerned with

*routing* traffic across and to networks. The protocol was first detailed by the IEEE in 1974 and comes from the

Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) project, which created the first large, packet-switched network.

Most people are familiar with IP addresses, the unique number given to a host participating in an IP network. Currently

there are two main versions of the IP protocol, IPv4 and IPv6, and one of the major differences is in how many IP

addresses are available. IPv4 supports 32 bit addresses and IPv6 supports 128 bit addresses. To give an idea of how big

of a change that is, we have currently allocated all possible IPv4 addresses, but with IPv6 we could give an address to

every grain of sand on the beaches of earth and still not run out.

<aside class="sidebar titled" title="IPv6 Security Implications" epub:type="sidebar">
topic: Broader applications of IP beyond the Internet and the adaptability of the protocol to other networking scenarios.
question: Which architectural characteristic of the Internet Protocol (IP) most fundamentally enables its deployment in networking scenarios beyond the public Internet, including private or isolated environments?

choices.A: Its strict dependence on globally routable address assignments
choices.B: Its abstraction of routing from underlying physical network technologies
choices.C: Its integration of end-to-end encryption at the network layer
choices.D: Its limitation to packet-switched networks only

explanation: The defining feature that enables IP to be used in a wide range of environments is its abstraction of routing and addressing from the specifics of underlying physical network technologies, allowing it to function over diverse infrastructures, not just the global Internet. The other options either introduce incorrect dependencies (A), features IP does not natively provide (C), or misstate its flexibility (D).

### 3.6.1. Recon {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__recon}
Recon is short for reconnaissance, military parlance for a preliminary survey used to gain information. During the recon

phase, a malicious actor will gather as much information as possible. Methods used in this phase may be passive or

active.

Passive recon involves gathering information *without* sending anything to the target. This typically involves accessing

publicly available information, such as social media, published websites, and DNS records. If the actor has access they

may also passively sniff network packets.

Active recon involves interaction with the target. This can include port scanning, vulnerability scanning, [brute

forcing directories and filenames on an HTTP server](https://www.kali.org/tools/dirbuster/){.link}, or even contacting

workers. Active recon can yield more information, but it is also significantly easier to detect.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.2. Weaponization"}


### 3.6.2. Weaponization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__weaponization}
In the weaponization phase the actor begins readying exploits for the vulnerabilities that were assessed during recon.

This may include tailoring malware, creating phishing emails, customizing tools, and preparing an environment for the

attack. For malware to be effective it must utilize the correct exploits and work under the correct OS and environment.

[Metasploit](https://www.metasploit.com/){.link} is a penetration testing framework that is often used in this step to

create custom malware.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.3. Delivery"}
topic: The security implications of publicly available information and organizational exposure during the recon phase.
question: Which of the following best explains why passive reconnaissance leveraging publicly available information poses a unique challenge to organizational security during the recon phase?

choices.A: Because it primarily targets technical vulnerabilities that can be patched through regular updates.
choices.B: Because it can reveal sensitive organizational details without alerting defenders, enabling attackers to plan tailored attacks while remaining undetected.
choices.C: Because it requires sophisticated malware to extract meaningful data from public sources.
choices.D: Because it is only effective against organizations with weak firewall configurations.

explanation: Passive reconnaissance is difficult for organizations to detect, as it relies on collecting information already publicly accessible (such as social media, websites, and DNS records). This can provide attackers with sensitive organizational details without triggering alarms or defensive responses, allowing for the planning of highly targeted attacks while remaining unnoticed. The other options mischaracterize the nature and impact of passive reconnaissance.

question: In the context of system security and policy enforcement, what is a significant risk introduced when user-level processes are permitted to deploy network services on non-well-known ports, compared to restricting service deployment to administrative-level privileges on well-known ports?

choices.A: It becomes possible for unauthorized users to run services that mimic legitimate ones, undermining security controls based on port assignments.
choices.B: Network traffic cannot be monitored or filtered when services use non-well-known ports.
choices.C: The operating system is unable to distinguish between different user processes running on non-well-known ports.
choices.D: Encryption protocols cannot be used on services running on non-well-known ports.

The other options are incorrect: network traffic can still be monitored/filtered regardless of port, the OS can distinguish processes, and encryption is independent of port number.

### 10.1.5. PaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__paas}
PaaS stands for platform as a service and refers to a higher-level service that deploys an application in an already

established environment running on an IaaS service. Heroku is a great example of this type of service.

Heroku supports many different applications, but they all work in relatively the same manner: Imagine there is a git

repository of a Django web application that needs to be deployed. Heroku will take an Amazon EC2 instance running on

AWS, clone the repo, install a Python virtual environment with the needed dependencies, and install a production Django

web server on the system.

While the user could take these steps themselves, PaaS makes it easier to deploy an application.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.6. SaaS"}


### 10.1.6. SaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__saas}
Software as a service (SaaS) is a methodology that we are quite used to. SaaS takes a web application and makes it

available for a subscription. Some examples would be Webex, Dropbox, Google Workspace, etc. SaaS is a popular way to

monitize software.

One of the security concerns with SaaS is that it consolidates information with a single provider. If the server running

the software is compromised, the PII of millions of people may be leaked.

:::

### 4.4.9. DNS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dns}
Domain Name System (DNS) is used to resolve domain names to IP addresses. Domain names are the simple names people are

accustomed to for websites, such as `njit.edu`{.literal} as opposed to `54.83.189.142`{.literal}. Names are

significantly easier for people to remember than IP addresses. In order for a computer to resolve a name, it first

queries a local cache, then its primary DNS server. Assuming the DNS server cannot find the name it will query a Root

server for a Top Level Domain (TLD) server, which maintains a listing of Authoritative Nameservers for that particular

domain (edu, com, net, org, gov, etc.). Finally once an authoritative nameserver is found it will respond with the IP

address for that particular hostname which will be cached and sent back through the user's primary DNS server to the

user.

DNS is designed to be resilient and decentralized but unfortunately the traffic is not authenticated or encrypted. This

has made it a target for MitM attacks. Likewise cache hits and misses [can yield information as to what names have been

recently resolved](https://kb.isc.org/docs/aa-00509){.link} (as was the case in discovering the extent of the Sony

Rootkit). The recursive nature has of DNS has also allowed for DoS attacks in the past, but much of that has been solved

by limiting recursive queries to the user-facing DNS servers (ie. the one given to you by your DHCP request). DNS

operates via UDP (and occasionally TCP) on port 53.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.10. DNSSEC"}
topic: The technical protocols and ports used by DNS and their implications for network security.
question: Which aspect of DNS's use of UDP and TCP on port 53 most significantly contributes to its susceptibility to specific attack vectors, and why does restricting recursive queries primarily mitigate one class of threat rather than another?

choices.A: UDP's connectionless nature enables easy spoofing, facilitating cache poisoning and amplification attacks, while restricting recursion primarily mitigates DoS risks rather than interception.
choices.B: TCP's overhead increases latency, making DNS slow, and restricting recursion prevents all forms of DNS data exfiltration.
choices.C: UDP's small packet size limits DNS response data, preventing data leakage, and recursion restriction eliminates the risk of MitM attacks.
choices.D: TCP's reliability ensures secure transmissions, so only UDP-based DNS needs security measures, and recursion restriction defends against both cache poisoning and DoS.

explanation: UDP's lack of connection establishment makes it vulnerable to spoofed requests (enabling cache poisoning and amplification DoS attacks), while restricting recursion mainly prevents DNS servers from being abused in DoS attacks by limiting how many queries they resolve on behalf of others, but does not prevent interception or poisoning, which are enabled by lack of authentication and encryption.

### 3.6.6. Command and Control (C2, C&C) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__command_and_control_c2_cc}
Malware will reach out via its Command and Control channel for more instructions. At this point an attacker may interact

with the malware, giving it additional commands. C2 traffic is usually designed to blend in with existing traffic and

not draw attention.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives"}


### 3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__exfiltration_actions_objectives}
The final step involves getting data from the exploited systems or disabling/misusing the systems in another way. At

this point an attacker can use the C2 channel to pull sensitive information from the system, credit card information,

password hashes, etc. Its important to not that exfiltration of data may not be the only goal of the attack. An attacker

can also disable the system, commit fraud with the system, mine crypto currencies, etc. At this point the malicious

actor is in complete control of the exploited system.

:::

topic: The role of C2 channels in enabling post-exploitation attacker activities, including real-time command execution.
question: Which property most fundamentally distinguishes C2 channels in enabling post-exploitation attacker activities such as real-time command execution?

choices.A: They provide a covert means for initial access to the target system.
choices.B: They allow persistent, interactive communication that enables dynamic attacker objectives beyond automated payload delivery.
choices.C: They solely facilitate rapid exfiltration of data from compromised hosts.
choices.D: They guarantee that all attacker actions remain undetectable by network monitoring tools.

explanation: C2 channels are uniquely characterized by enabling persistent, interactive control over compromised systems, allowing attackers to execute dynamic objectives in real-time, not just automated or pre-scripted actions.

In the [Malware](#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__malware){.xref} chapter we covered Lockheed

own sub-techniques.

### 9.5.1. Reconnaissance {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__reconnaissance}
Reconnaissance is the act of collecting information about a target. This typically involves vulnerability scanning,

network mapping, and phishing. Attackers are generally looking for weak links and a way in to the company. Understanding

how reconnaissance is performed can help a security team pick up on the precursors to an incident.

:::

topic: The critical role of comprehensive frameworks like MITRE ATT&CK in guiding security team decision-making and response strategies.
question: Which aspect of the MITRE ATT&CK framework most fundamentally enhances a security team's ability to make informed response and continuity decisions compared to linear models like the Cyber Killchain?

choices.A: Its detailed mapping of adversary tactics, techniques, and sub-techniques across multiple matrices.
choices.B: Its exclusive focus on post-compromise activities for incident response.
choices.C: Its strict chronological ordering of attack stages, enforcing a linear defense workflow.
choices.D: Its reliance on static vulnerability databases for automated network scanning.

explanation: The most fundamental enhancement ATT&CK offers is its granular and multi-dimensional mapping of adversary behaviors, allowing teams to identify and respond to specific tactics and techniques at any stage of an attack, not just in a linear sequence. This contrasts with linear models and enables more flexible, informed, and proactive decision-making.

## 4.1. Network Access Layer {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__network_access_layer}
::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.1. ARP"}


### 4.1.1. ARP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__arp}
Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is used on the local ethernet segment to resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses. Since

this protocol functions at the ethernet segment level, security was not a primary concern. Unfortunately this means that

ARP communications can be easily spoofed to cause a MitM scenario. A malicious actor simply sends out several ARP

packets, *gratuitous arp*, saying that traffic for a certain IP address should be sent to them. Since the MAC to IP

address table is cached in several places, it can take a long time for all the caches to invalidate and resolve an issue

caused by malicious ARP frames.

There is a protocol designed to mitigate the issues with ARP. Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) reaches across layers to work

with the DHCP lease database and drop packets that are not using the MAC address used when a DHCP lease was granted.

While this can solve many of the issues associated with ARP it is also a good practice to use secure higher-level

protocols such as HTTPS just in case.

:::

:::: {.section .sect3 title="4.1.2. Wifi"}
topic: Detailed explanation of the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) and its function within the network access layer.
question: In a network utilizing both static and dynamic IP address assignments, what is the most significant limitation of Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) as a mitigation for ARP spoofing attacks, and why does this limitation persist despite DAI's integration with DHCP databases?

choices.A: DAI cannot validate ARP packets for statically assigned IP addresses without manual configuration, allowing spoofing in such cases.
choices.B: DAI increases ARP traffic latency, making real-time communication unreliable for all hosts.
choices.C: DAI encrypts ARP traffic, which can cause compatibility issues with legacy network devices.
choices.D: DAI disables ARP cache updates, leading to frequent network address resolution failures.

explanation: DAI relies on DHCP lease information to validate ARP packets, but for statically assigned IP addresses (which are not recorded in the DHCP database), DAI cannot automatically determine the legitimate MAC-IP mapping. Unless static bindings are manually configured, ARP spoofing can still occur for these addresses.
