topic: The foundational purpose and function of the Internet Protocol (IP) in enabling a network of networks and its central role in Internet routing.

SNMP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__snmp} ::: float-group Simple Network Management Protocol is used for gathering information about the workings of a network. choices.B: The use of distinct UDP ports for clients and managers, which can be easily identified by attackers.
choices.C: The protocol’s reliance on UDP, which lacks reliable delivery and session management.
choices.D: The necessity for SNMP managers to broadcast requests to all network clients.

explanation: The primary risk arises from SNMP’s ability to transmit detailed operational metrics about devices and network usage. This data can reveal sensitive information about network architecture, device roles, and real-time status, providing attackers with actionable intelligence for planning further attacks. While port usage, protocol type, and communication patterns are relevant, they are less critical than the exposure of internal operational metrics.

topic: Analyze the inherent vulnerabilities of wireless networking and explain how Wifi security standards address these risks.
question: Which of the following most accurately explains how the evolution of Wifi security standards addresses the inherent vulnerabilities of wireless networks, and why only the latest standards are considered secure today?

choices.A: WEP and WPA used static keys vulnerable to interception, while WPA2 introduced dynamic RC4 keys, and WPA3 replaced them with more efficient 24-bit encryption.
choices.B: WEP relied on a weak RC4 stream cipher with a small initialization vector, WPA improved key rotation but still used vulnerable encryption, WPA2 adopted AES-based encryption to mitigate these flaws, and WPA3 introduced further enhancements to resist modern attacks.
choices.C: WPA2 and WPA3 both use RC4 with longer keys, making brute-force attacks impractical, while WEP and WPA used AES but with flawed key management.
choices.D: All Wifi security standards provide equivalent protection, but WPA3 is preferred due to faster authentication speeds.

explanation: Option B correctly traces the technical evolution: WEP's use of RC4 and a 24-bit IV made it highly vulnerable; WPA introduced TKIP for key rotation but retained RC4, leaving it susceptible to attacks; WPA2 replaced RC4/TKIP with AES, significantly increasing security; WPA3 further improves upon WPA2 to counteract new attack vectors. Other options contain technical inaccuracies regarding cipher usage and protocol progression.

## 6.1. False Positives / Negatives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__false_positives_negatives}
When a security solution detects a threat, but no threat exists, that is a *false positive*. Depending on the complexity

of the solution it may utilize a set of rules, indicators of compromise, or possibly even artificial intelligence to

trigger its warning system. In the case of a solution that creates a lot of false positives, it can be tiring for a team

to go through each alert. Eventually teams are conditioned to ignore the alerts, making the security solution useless.

The key to lowering the false positive rate of a system is to better tune the rule set used to trigger the warnings. A

security team may spend time determining a baseline of events and looking for abnormalities that correspond to actual

attacks. This information can then be used to build a better detection system.

::::: example

::: example-title

Webroot Antivirus

:::

::: example-content

[In 2017 a popular antivirus service created a bad rule that identified certain Windows operating system files as

threats.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/popular-antivirus-program-mistakenly-ids-windows-threat-creating-chaos-n750521){.link}

The antivirus solution quarantined these files, which were critical for the operation of the machine. The result was a

machine that was unusable.

For 13 minutes, Webroot distributed this rule to its antivirus software shutting down operations on an untold number of

machines. Fortunately Webroot was able to quickly identify the problem and send out an update which would have allowed

the machines to automatically fix the problem. Unfortunately their infrastructure for distributing the update quickly

became overloaded.

:::

:::::

When a security solution fails to identify a threat, this is known as a *false negative*. While no solution can ever be

100% effective, false negatives can undermine confidence in a product. False negatives may be resolved by a skilled SOC

team, closely monitoring what is happening. It is also possible to address false negatives through *Layered Security* a

concept that we will cover next.

::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="6.2. Layered Security"}
topic: Real-world consequences of false positives in security software, illustrated by the 2017 Webroot Antivirus incident.
question: Which of the following best explains the most critical operational risk revealed by the 2017 Webroot Antivirus incident involving false positives?

choices.A: The inability of the antivirus software to detect novel threats due to outdated signature databases.
choices.B: The escalation of a minor detection error into widespread business disruption due to critical system file quarantine and insufficient update distribution capacity.
choices.C: The permanent loss of user data caused by the antivirus software deleting user files without recovery options.
choices.D: The failure of the antivirus software to provide adequate logging for forensic analysis after an incident.

explanation: The most critical operational risk illustrated by the Webroot incident was not simply the initial false positive, but how a misconfigured detection rule led to the quarantine of critical OS files, making machines unusable. The risk was exacerbated by Webroot's infrastructure being unable to promptly distribute the corrective update, causing prolonged business disruption. The other options either misrepresent the incident (A, C, D) or do not capture the systemic escalation of risk.

topic: Reflect on the potential strengths and weaknesses in the distribution and emphasis of organizational versus technical content within the course schedule.
question: In the presented 15-week computer systems security course schedule, what is the most significant potential weakness arising from the sequencing and clustering of organizational content relative to technical content, and how might this impact student competency development?

choices.A: Organizational topics are concentrated in later weeks, risking insufficient reinforcement and integration with technical skills, which may hinder students' ability to contextualize technical concepts within real-world organizational practices.
choices.B: Technical topics are postponed until after foundational organizational material, potentially causing confusion regarding underlying mechanisms and reducing technical mastery.
choices.C: The consistent alternation of organizational and technical topics each week causes cognitive overload, diluting focus on either area and impeding deep learning.
choices.D: Organizational content is interleaved with technical labs in every week, leading to excessive breadth at the expense of technical depth.

explanation: The most significant weakness is the clustering of organizational content predominantly in the latter part of the course, rather than integrating it throughout. This sequencing can limit opportunities for students to relate technical skills to organizational contexts as they progress, diminishing the holistic development of competencies necessary for effective security practice.

# 10. Virtualization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__virtualization}
Information Technology has seen massive growth in the adoption of virtualization as the underpinning of dynamic and

robust systems. This shift from bare-metal resources to virtual resources provides its own unique security challenges

and considerations. As the field changes, it is important for anyone working in cybersecurity to not only understand how

these systems work, but also be able to approach their implementation with a security-first mindset.

::::::::: {.section .sect2 title="10.1. Methods"}
topic: Analyzing the security challenges unique to the transition from bare-metal to virtualized IT environments and their implications for modern cybersecurity practice.
question: Which of the following best illustrates a security challenge unique to virtualized IT environments, and why does it fundamentally shift the approach required in modern cybersecurity compared to bare-metal systems?

choices.A: Increased risk of hardware failure affecting multiple systems, since virtual machines depend on shared physical hosts.
choices.B: The potential for a compromised virtual machine to exploit hypervisor vulnerabilities and gain control over other VMs, necessitating new isolation and monitoring strategies.
choices.C: Greater susceptibility to physical theft of servers, since more data is consolidated on fewer machines in data centers.
choices.D: The persistent risk of malware infection within operating systems, requiring traditional endpoint protection measures.

explanation: Only option B describes a risk (VM escape via hypervisor exploitation) that is unique to virtualized environments, fundamentally altering security paradigms by demanding strong hypervisor security, rigorous VM isolation, and advanced monitoring—issues not encountered in traditional bare-metal deployments.

### 10.1.5. PaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__paas}
PaaS stands for platform as a service and refers to a higher-level service that deploys an application in an already

established environment running on an IaaS service. Heroku is a great example of this type of service.

Heroku supports many different applications, but they all work in relatively the same manner: Imagine there is a git

repository of a Django web application that needs to be deployed. Heroku will take an Amazon EC2 instance running on

AWS, clone the repo, install a Python virtual environment with the needed dependencies, and install a production Django

web server on the system.

While the user could take these steps themselves, PaaS makes it easier to deploy an application.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.6. SaaS"}


### 10.1.6. SaaS {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__saas}
Software as a service (SaaS) is a methodology that we are quite used to. SaaS takes a web application and makes it

available for a subscription. Some examples would be Webex, Dropbox, Google Workspace, etc. SaaS is a popular way to

monitize software.

One of the security concerns with SaaS is that it consolidates information with a single provider. If the server running

the software is compromised, the PII of millions of people may be leaked.

:::

:::::::::

::::::: {.section .sect2 title="10.2. Cloud Computing"}
topic: Detailed operational steps and automation provided by PaaS platforms like Heroku for deploying web applications.
question: Which sequence most accurately reflects the order of automated operational steps performed by a PaaS platform like Heroku when deploying a Django web application from a git repository, and which aspect distinguishes this process from manual deployment on an IaaS platform?

choices.A: Provision EC2 instance → Install Django server → Clone repository → Create Python virtual environment → Install dependencies; distinguished by automated infrastructure scaling.
choices.B: Clone repository → Provision EC2 instance → Install dependencies → Create Python virtual environment → Install Django server; distinguished by automated dependency resolution.
choices.C: Provision EC2 instance → Clone repository → Create Python virtual environment → Install dependencies → Install Django server; distinguished by automation of environment setup and application deployment.
choices.D: Install Django server → Provision EC2 instance → Clone repository → Install dependencies → Create Python virtual environment; distinguished by deployment through containerization.

explanation: The correct sequence is: provision the EC2 instance (infrastructure), clone the repository (application code), create the Python virtual environment (runtime isolation), install dependencies (application requirements), and finally install the production Django server (application runtime). The key distinguishing factor is automation of both environment setup and application deployment, abstracting these complex steps from the user.

MitB {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__mitb} MitB stands for man in the browser and is typically caused by a trojan installing malware that allows the attacker to intercept/modify communications between the browser and the server. This can be used to capture data on forms, modify input, or modify the response from the server. Often the software used in MitB attacks lays dormant until the victim browses to a targeted website. What follows is an example of how a MitB attack can be used to modify an online banking request to send money: As you can see the attacker ended up with \$10,000 and the victim simply thought they authorized a payment of \$1,000 to someone else. These attacks can be difficult to detect because they take place within the browser and are opportunistic. ::: :::: {.section .sect3 title="5.1.3. Replay Attacks"} ### 5.1.3. Replay Attacks {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__replay_attacks} This family of attacks typically involves a MitM making a copy of the transmission and *replaying* it to impersonate the victim. Logon credentials, simple hashes, and specific commands are sometimes susceptible to this type of attack. The solution is to use timestamps, nonces (random number for that particular session), rotating keys, or a counter to make sure commands cannot be executed outside of context.
topic: Discuss the real-world implications and potential consequences of MitB attacks, particularly in the context of online banking and financial fraud.
question: Which of the following best describes a primary real-world consequence of MitB attacks in online banking that distinguishes them from other forms of financial fraud?

choices.A: They allow attackers to compromise server-side databases directly, bypassing user interaction.
choices.B: They can alter transaction details within the user's browser session, making fraudulent transfers appear legitimate to both the user and the bank.
choices.C: They rely solely on intercepting network traffic outside the browser, making detection by endpoint security tools straightforward.
choices.D: They typically require physical access to the victim’s device to succeed, limiting their scalability.

explanation: Option B accurately captures the unique aspect of MitB attacks—the ability to manipulate transaction data within the browser in real time, so that fraudulent transactions are seamlessly integrated into the user’s session, escaping both user suspicion and many server-side checks. The other options either conflate MitB with unrelated attack vectors or incorrectly describe its mechanisms.

### 10.2.3. Hybrid {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__hybrid}
Hybrid cloud uses both models, public and private, and hosts some things on public IaaS services and other on internal,

private IaaS services. This can be the best of both worlds, assuming the applications being supported leverage the full

advantages of their environment.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.2.4. Multi-Cloud"}


### 10.2.4. Multi-Cloud {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__multi_cloud}
Multi-cloud typically refers to utilizing more than one cloud provider. This may be required for applications that wish

to remain available even if their cloud provider fails. Multi-cloud also avoids the issue of vendor lock-in, where the

application is only set up to run on one provider.

From a security standpoint, multi-cloud likely increases the attack surface of an application. You now have to be

concerned with the vulnerabilities of two providers instead of just one. This must be weighed against the benefits of

redundancy when deciding whether or not to utilize more than one cloud provider.

:::

:::::::

::: {.section .sect2 title="10.3. Serverless Solutions"}
topic: Examination of how multi-cloud deployment mitigates vendor lock-in and enhances application availability.
question: Which of the following best explains how a multi-cloud deployment simultaneously mitigates vendor lock-in and enhances application availability, while also introducing a critical security consideration?

choices.A: By distributing workloads across multiple providers, applications avoid dependency on proprietary APIs and remain operational if one provider fails, though this approach inherently expands the system's attack surface.
choices.B: By centralizing all workloads on a single provider, applications can leverage proprietary features to maximize uptime, but this centralization eliminates concerns about increased attack surfaces.
choices.C: By isolating critical workloads in private clouds and non-critical ones in public clouds, organizations reduce their reliance on vendors and improve security, but availability is not inherently increased.
choices.D: By using only public cloud services from a single region, applications can scale rapidly and avoid security vulnerabilities, thereby reducing both lock-in and attack surfaces.

explanation: Only option A correctly identifies that multi-cloud deployment reduces vendor lock-in by avoiding reliance on one provider, increases availability by providing redundancy in case of provider failure, and introduces a larger attack surface due to managing multiple providers.

context: ### 3.5.6. Impersonation/Identity Theft {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__impersonationidentity_theft} Often as part of a phishing campaign, a threat actor will pretend to be someone else. This may be someone within the organization or someone with sufficient power outside the organization, such as a representative of a government oversight agency. Attackers may also use stolen credentials to make their messages appear official, once again giving them and easy route through which to deploy malware. ::: :::::::::: :::::::::: {.section .sect2 title="3.6. Cyber Killchain"} ## 3.6. Cyber Killchain {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cyber_killchain} One way of analyzing an attack involving malware is through the steps of the Cyber Killchain. The Cyber Killchain was developed by Lockheed Martin and is a military method of analysis that has been adopted by cybersecurity. Cyber Killchain is broken into seven steps: Recon, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, Command and Control, and Exfiltration. ::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.1. Recon"}
topic: Limitations and potential improvements of the Cyber Killchain framework in modern cybersecurity practice.
question: Which of the following most accurately describes a significant limitation of the Cyber Killchain framework in the context of modern cybersecurity threats, and proposes a substantive improvement to address it?

choices.A: The Cyber Killchain's linear progression inadequately models multi-vector, iterative, or post-exploitation activities; incorporating feedback loops and continuous monitoring would better address adaptive threat behaviors.
choices.B: The Cyber Killchain fails to account for reconnaissance activities; adding pre-attack intelligence steps would align it with modern threats.
choices.C: The Cyber Killchain overemphasizes insider threats while neglecting external actors; rebalancing focus toward external actors would enhance its applicability.
choices.D: The Cyber Killchain's technical focus excludes legal and compliance considerations; integrating regulatory controls into each phase would resolve this issue.

explanation: The primary limitation of the Cyber Killchain is its linear, phase-based structure, which does not effectively capture the complexity of modern attacks involving iterative, multi-stage, and social engineering tactics. Adding feedback mechanisms and embracing continuous monitoring enables the framework to more accurately reflect and respond to adaptive, non-linear threat activities. The other options either mischaracterize the framework’s current focus or suggest improvements that do not directly address its main limitations.

context: ## One-time Passwords ::: content To help mitigate replay attacks, an online banking application may require that client use a one-time password (OTP) when submitting transactions. An OTP is a frequently changing value that is known to both the client and the server. Several one-time password schemes exist, most of which make use of a cryptographic hash function with a shared seed between client and server. Periodically the client and server update to a new hash based on the seed and without the seed it is impossible to know what the next hash will be. By using an OTP anyone who intercepts the traffic will not be able to perform a replay attack as the password will not be current. ::: :::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="5.1.4. SSL Circumvention"} ### 5.1.4. SSL Circumvention {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ssl_circumvention} If you think about the intercepted key exchange given in the above MitM example, a similar attack can allow attackers to view SSL traffic. The attacker gives the victim a bogus certificate authority (CA) certificate which the victim installs. This is often accomplished via a trojan. Then the attacker places themselves in the middle of an uninitiated secure connection. During the key exchange the attacker creates a custom certificate signed by a bogus CA for the connection between attacker and victim. The attacker also makes an actual HTTPS connection to the service and proxies data for the victim. All of the victims data will show up in plaintext for the attacker but the connection will appear to be secure for the victim. This is used in the [Fiddler](https://www.telerik.com/fiddler){.link} debugging proxy to decrypt HTTPS traffic and is also used in some network appliances that perform deep packet inspection. Another MitM attack on SSL is simply to maintain or downgrade to an HTTP connection with the victim and proxy data to an actual HTTPS connection with the server. Most servers will upgrade an insecure connection, but by intercepting that exchange the attacker can continue to monitor the victim's traffic. ::: :::::::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="5.2. Network Layer Attacks"}
topic: Legitimate uses of SSL MitM techniques, such as debugging proxies and network appliances, and the associated security trade-offs.
question: Which of the following best describes a primary security trade-off when deploying legitimate SSL MitM appliances (such as debugging proxies or network inspection devices) within an enterprise environment?

choices.A: They increase risk by requiring installation of custom root CA certificates, potentially making users vulnerable to external MitM attacks if the CA is compromised.
choices.B: They only affect performance but do not alter the risk profile of encrypted communications in the enterprise.
choices.C: They eliminate the possibility of external attackers intercepting SSL traffic by centralizing all decryption within the enterprise network.
choices.D: They guarantee that all intercepted traffic remains secure, provided the appliance itself is not externally reachable.

explanation: Installing custom root CA certificates for SSL interception allows the appliance to decrypt HTTPS traffic, but if the CA certificate is compromised or mismanaged, attackers can impersonate secure sites, exposing users to MitM attacks both inside and outside the enterprise.

topic: The concept, application, and limitations of virus definitions or signatures as IoCs, particularly regarding detection of hidden or obfuscated malware.
question: Which scenario most accurately illustrates a fundamental limitation of relying solely on virus definitions or signatures as indicators of compromise in detecting advanced malware threats?

choices.A: Malware that encrypts its communication channels to remote servers, making network activity analysis ineffective.
choices.B: Malware that dynamically changes its byte patterns or structure through obfuscation or polymorphism, preventing reliable signature matching.
choices.C: Malware that deletes system logs after execution, leaving no forensic artifacts for investigators to examine.
choices.D: Malware that exclusively targets Linux systems, while existing signatures are focused on Windows malware.

explanation: Signature-based detection depends on recognizing specific, static byte patterns unique to known malware. Advanced malware can evade this by altering its code structure or appearance on each infection (polymorphism) or employing obfuscation techniques, resulting in unique or unpredictable signatures that signature-based scanners cannot reliably detect. Other scenarios, such as encrypted communications or log deletion, involve different detection challenges not directly related to signature limitations.

topic: The relationship between port allocation, service exposure, and vulnerability to common network attacks such as port scanning and unauthorized access.
question: Which scenario most increases a host's vulnerability to port scanning and unauthorized access, given the interplay of port allocation, privilege requirements, and service exposure?

choices.A: Running only essential services on well-known ports, with all other ports closed by default.
choices.B: Allowing non-administrative users to run arbitrary services on registered ports, leaving them open to the network.
choices.C: Restricting all dynamic ports and using only well-known ports for every service, including custom applications.
choices.D: Binding all services to high-numbered dynamic ports above 49152 and firewalling all lower ports.

explanation: Allowing non-administrative users to run arbitrary services on registered ports (1024–49151) exposes a broad range of ports to the network, often without rigorous oversight or privilege restrictions, making them prime targets for port scanning and unauthorized access. Attackers can exploit these open registered ports, which may host insecure or poorly configured services, increasing the overall attack surface.

### 3.6.6. Command and Control (C2, C&C) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__command_and_control_c2_cc}
Malware will reach out via its Command and Control channel for more instructions. At this point an attacker may interact

with the malware, giving it additional commands. C2 traffic is usually designed to blend in with existing traffic and

not draw attention.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives"}


### 3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__exfiltration_actions_objectives}
The final step involves getting data from the exploited systems or disabling/misusing the systems in another way. At

this point an attacker can use the C2 channel to pull sensitive information from the system, credit card information,

password hashes, etc. Its important to not that exfiltration of data may not be the only goal of the attack. An attacker

can also disable the system, commit fraud with the system, mine crypto currencies, etc. At this point the malicious

actor is in complete control of the exploited system.

:::

:::::: {.section .sect2 title="3.7. Lab: Malware Analysis"}
topic: Alternative attacker objectives post-exploitation, including system disabling, fraud, and illicit resource usage such as cryptocurrency mining.
question: Which scenario best exemplifies an attacker leveraging post-exploitation access for objectives other than data exfiltration?

choices.A: The attacker harvests employee credentials from the compromised system for resale on dark web forums.
choices.B: The attacker installs a cryptocurrency miner, causing significant CPU usage and performance degradation.
choices.C: The attacker uses the system to access confidential corporate documents and transmits them to an external server.
choices.D: The attacker captures and exports credit card data stored on the compromised machine.

explanation: Option B illustrates illicit resource usage—specifically, unauthorized cryptocurrency mining—without involving data theft, aligning directly with alternative post-exploitation objectives. The other scenarios all focus on various forms of data exfiltration.

topic: Techniques for mitigating ICMP Flood attacks, particularly the implementation and challenges of rate limiting.
question: Which of the following is a primary challenge in implementing rate limiting as a mitigation against ICMP Flood attacks on production servers?

choices.A: It can prevent all forms of distributed denial of service attacks by blocking ICMP traffic entirely.
choices.B: It risks inadvertently disrupting legitimate network diagnostic and control functions that rely on ICMP.
choices.C: It allows attackers to bypass protection by switching to TCP-based attacks.
choices.D: It requires specialized hardware that is unavailable in most modern server environments.

explanation: The main challenge with rate limiting ICMP traffic is that legitimate network operations—including diagnostics like ping and network error reporting—depend on ICMP. Overly aggressive rate limiting can disrupt these necessary functions, causing operational issues even in the absence of an attack.

topic: Discuss the educational value and challenges of incorporating real-world case studies (such as the 2014 Sony Pictures hack) into the curriculum for incident response training.
question: Which of the following most accurately characterizes both the educational value and the primary pedagogical challenge of integrating a real-world case study like the 2014 Sony Pictures hack into an incident response curriculum?

choices.A: It provides authentic context for applying theoretical knowledge, but may inadvertently promote an oversimplified, linear view of incident response processes.
choices.B: It increases student engagement through sensationalism, but risks distracting from essential technical content due to media bias.
choices.C: It offers a safe environment for skills practice, but often fails to connect with broader organizational security policies.
choices.D: It standardizes assessment criteria, but reduces opportunities for collaborative analysis and critical thinking.

explanation: Option A best synthesizes the dual impact: real-world cases make theory applicable and engaging, yet the process of turning a complex, chaotic incident into a classroom exercise can unintentionally encourage students to see incident response as a straightforward sequence, when in reality it is often non-linear and ambiguous. The other options either mischaracterize the challenge (B, C) or inaccurately describe the educational value (D).
